title: Histological assessment of developmental cell death in Drosophila pupae
procedures:
Step-by-step method details
Step-by-step method details
Collection and fixation of Drosophila pupae
Timing: approximately 2–5 days
The steps below describe how to collect and fix Drosophila pupae of the appropriate developmental stage, to investigate the role of different genes in the clearance of the larval salivary glands during metamorphosis.
Collect white prepupae (WPP) from the side wall of a culture vial (Figure 1[href=https://www.wicell.org#fig1]A) using a pair of forceps and place them in a 35 mm petri dish lined with a piece of wet tissue paper (Figure 1[href=https://www.wicell.org#fig1]B).
imgsrc:https://prod-shared-star-protocols.s3.amazonaws.com/protocols/608-Fig1.jpg
Figure 1. .Collecting and preparing pupae for fixation
(A) White prepupa (WPP) (circle).
(B) Collected WPP in a petri dish lined with wet tissue paper.
(C) 24 h APF pupa (arrows indicate the position of the cuts).
(D) 24 h APF pupa after the cuts have been made (arrows point to the cut sites).
Note: New WPP form on the side wall of the culture vial every hour and can be collected multiple times each day.
Incubate the WPP- containing petri dish in a 25°C incubator with a 16 h day/8 h night cycle for exactly 24 h.
Critical: After 24 h of incubation, the animals should have transitioned from the pre-pupal to the pupal stage. Do not use animals that are still in the pre-pupal stage (troubleshooting 1[href=https://www.wicell.org#sec7.1]).
Using a pair of forceps, submerge a pupa in a concave slide containing PBS (Figure 1[href=https://www.wicell.org#fig1]C and Methods video S1[href=https://www.wicell.org#mmc1]).
Using a pair of dissecting scissors incise the pupal case first at the anterior end of the pupa and then at the posterior end (Figure 1[href=https://www.wicell.org#fig1]D, Methods video S1[href=https://www.wicell.org#mmc1]).
Puncture the cuticle at the posterior end of the developing animal using the tip of the dissecting scissors or a needle (Figure 1[href=https://www.wicell.org#fig1]D and Methods video S1[href=https://www.wicell.org#mmc1]).

Critical: During the process, be careful not to severely damage the developing animal inside the pupal case. When puncturing the cuticle or when cutting the pupal case at the posterior end of the animal, a small amount of tissue might leak out of the cut. These pupae can still be used unless they have sustained excessive damage (troubleshooting 2[href=https://www.wicell.org#sec7.3]).
Transfer the pupae to an Eppendorf tube with 500 μL of fixative solution.
Incubate the pupae in fixative at 4°C for 48 h.
Pause Point: After step 7 the animals can be stored in the fixative solution for at least two weeks without any noticeable variation.
Note: Collect at least 20 animals from each genotype/condition. The collection and fixation process can last several days. Animals of the same genotype/condition collected at different times/days can be added to the same tube.

Embedding Drosophila pupae in paraffin
Timing: approximately 2 days
These steps describe the process of embedding the Drosophila pupae in paraffin.
Discard the fixative solution and add 500 μL of 80% ethanol to the pupae.
Rotate the pupae with ethanol on a nutator at 20°C–25°C for 15 min.
Discard 80% ethanol and add 500 μL of 85% ethanol.
Rotate on a nutator at 20°C–25°C for 20 min.
Discard 85% ethanol and add 500 μL of 90% ethanol.
Rotate on a nutator at 20°C–25°C for 25 min.
Discard 90% ethanol and add 500 μL of 100% ethanol.
Rotate on a nutator at 20°C–25°C for 30 min.
Discard 100% ethanol and add 500 μL of fresh 100% ethanol.
Rotate on a nutator at 20°C–25°C for 30 min.
Repeat steps 16 and 17 two additional times.

Discard the 100% ethanol from the tube and add 500 μL of 100% xylene.
Rotate on a nutator at 20°C–25°C for 30 min.
Discard 100% xylene and add 500 μL of fresh 100% xylene.
Rotate on a nutator at 20°C–25°C for 30 min.
Repeat steps 21 and 22 two additional times.
In a 20 mL scintillation vial add:
~1.8 g of paraffin chips, Paraplast X-tra (not melted).
2 mL of 100% xylene.
Transfer the pupae into a scintillation vial.
Note: Add a maximum of 20 animals per vial. If more animals have been collected from one genotype/condition, split them into an appropriate number of vials.
Note: Remember to melt enough paraffin in a 56°C incubator which will be used the next day.
Incubate the pupae in a 42°C incubator for 16–20 h.
Discard the xylene/paraffin solution from the vial using a glass pipette.
Add an adequate amount of melted paraffin, enough to cover all of the pupae.
Incubate the vial containing the pupae in a 56°C incubator for 2 h.
Replace melted paraffin with fresh melted paraffin and incubate in a 56°C incubator for 2 h.
Repeat step 30 two additional times.
Pause Point: The procedure can be paused for at least one week.
Fill the vial with melted paraffin.
Incubate the vial in a 56°C incubator for at least 30 min.
Make a mold using a 3" × 5" white unruled index card (Figure 2[href=https://www.wicell.org#fig2]A and Methods video S2[href=https://www.wicell.org#mmc1]).
imgsrc:https://prod-shared-star-protocols.s3.amazonaws.com/protocols/608-Fig2.jpg
Figure 2. .Orientation of the processed pupae into the molds for embedding in paraffin
(A) Paper mold.
(B) Animals oriented in the molds and labeled.
Cover the slide warmer with aluminum foil and pre-heat it to 56°C.
Pre-heat the mold on the slide warmer.
Quickly pour the melted paraffin containing the pupae into the mold.

Orient the pupae, using a toothpick, with their ventral side facing down (spiracles pointing up) and ensure that there is an adequate amount of space between them. This step is to be performed quickly before the paraffin begins to harden (~3 min) (Figure 2[href=https://www.wicell.org#fig2]B and Methods video S3[href=https://www.wicell.org#mmc3] troubleshooting 3[href=https://www.wicell.org#sec7.5]).

Methods video S2. Construction of paper mold for paraffin embedding, related to step 34
Note: You can add a small piece of paper (i.e., a tag) with the genotype/condition corresponding to each mold. You can also position up to five animals, side by side, as shown in Figure 2[href=https://www.wicell.org#fig2]B.
Switch off the slide warmer and leave the molds containing the pupae to cool for 16–20 h.
Store the paraffin blocks with the embedded pupae at 20°C–25°C.
Pause Point: The paraffin blocks can be stored at 20°C–25°C indefinitely.

Sectioning of the embedded Drosophila pupae
Timing: approximately 1 day
Here we describe how to prepare the embedded animals for sectioning with a microtome. We also describe the key steps in the sectioning process.
Peel away the paper mold from the hardened paraffin block (Figure 3[href=https://www.wicell.org#fig3]A).
imgsrc:https://prod-shared-star-protocols.s3.amazonaws.com/protocols/608-Fig3.jpg
Figure 3. .Preparation of embedded animals for sectioning
(A) Animals embedded in paraffin.
(B) Small piece of paraffin that contains a group of animals.
(C) Embedded animals mounted on microtome chucks.
(D) Trimmed block of paraffin with pupae.
Cut the paraffin block into smaller, individual pyramid shaped blocks (Figure 3[href=https://www.wicell.org#fig3]B).
Mount a block on a microtome chuck by melting the paraffin on the bottom of the block and then letting it solidify on the microtome chuck (Figure 3[href=https://www.wicell.org#fig3]C).

Trim the blocks creating a truncated rectangular pyramid with only 0.5 mm of space surrounding the animals (Figure 3[href=https://www.wicell.org#fig3]D and Methods video S4[href=https://www.wicell.org#mmc4]).
Critical: Make sure the shape is a truncated rectangular pyramid to obtain a straight ribbon when sectioning (Figure 3[href=https://www.wicell.org#fig3]D and Methods video S4[href=https://www.wicell.org#mmc4]).
Place a microscope slide onto a 42°C slide warmer and add distilled water on top of it (Methods video S5[href=https://www.wicell.org#mmc5]).
    Your browser does not support HTML5 video.
  
Methods video S4. Trimming of the paraffin blocks, related to step 44
Note: Use a pencil or a chemical-resistant marker to label microscope slides.
Section using a microtome at 7 μm thickness (troubleshooting 4[href=https://www.wicell.org#sec7.7]).
Float sections onto a microscope slide with water (Methods video S5[href=https://www.wicell.org#mmc5]).
Let the sections expand for 1–2 min (Methods video S5[href=https://www.wicell.org#mmc5]).
Remove the water from the slide using a paper towel along the side (Methods video S5[href=https://www.wicell.org#mmc5]).
Leave the slides on the 42°C slide warmer for 16–20 h (Methods video S5[href=https://www.wicell.org#mmc5]).

Staining and image acquisition
Timing: approximately 4–6 h
In these steps we describe the process of staining the tissues on microscope slides.
Place the microscope slides into a slide rack (Figure 4[href=https://www.wicell.org#fig4]A).
imgsrc:https://prod-shared-star-protocols.s3.amazonaws.com/protocols/608-Fig4.jpg
Figure 4. .Staining of the tissue sections
(A) Containers with the solutions used during the staining procedure.
(B) Plastic container with slides in the slide rack, under running water.
(C) Slides with stained tissues after a coverslip has been mounted.
Rehydrate the tissue by incubating them sequentially in containers with the following solutions and time duration(s) under a chemical hood (Figure 4[href=https://www.wicell.org#fig4]A):
100% Xylene I for 3 min.
100% Xylene II for 3 min.
100% Ethanol I for 3 min.
100% Ethanol II for 3 min.
95% Ethanol I for 3 min.

75% Ethanol for 3 min
Running tap water for 5 min (Figure 4[href=https://www.wicell.org#fig4]B).
Critical: Use a large plastic container and do not let the stream of running water hit the slides (Figure 4[href=https://www.wicell.org#fig4]B, troubleshooting 5[href=https://www.wicell.org#sec7.9]).
Stain the tissue sections by incubating the slides containing the sections sequentially in containers with the following solutions and time duration(s):
Weigert’s Hematoxylin for 5 min.
Running tap water for 5 min (Figure 4[href=https://www.wicell.org#fig4]B).
Critical: Use a large plastic container and do not let the stream of running water hit the slides (Figure 4[href=https://www.wicell.org#fig4]B, troubleshooting 5[href=https://www.wicell.org#sec7.9]).
Pollak’s Trichrome for 7 min.
Distilled water for 10 s to remove the excess of stain.
0.2% glacial acetic acid in distilled water for 10 s.
Dehydrate the tissue sections by incubating in containers with the following solutions and time duration(s):
70% Ethanol 2–3 dips.
95% Ethanol II 2–3 dips.
95% Ethanol I for 3 min.
100% Ethanol I for 3 min.
100% Ethanol II for 3 min.
100% Xylene II for 3 min.
100% Xylene I for 3 min.
Dry the slides on a paper towel for 3 min.
Use ~80 μL of Permount per slide to mount a 50 mm coverslip on the sections.
Leave slides on a cardboard slide tray, at 20°C–25°C, for at least 2 h for the Permount to partially harden (Figure 4[href=https://www.wicell.org#fig4]C).
Using a brightfield microscope with a 5× objective, acquire representative images from each genotype/condition.
Note: Permount completely hardens after 24–48 h. Once Permount hardens, store slides in a slide box indefinitely.
